text:
But I was softened by the softened aspect of the man, and
felt a touch of reproach.
label: disgust

text:
“I hope,” said I, hurriedly putting something
into a glass for myself, and drawing a chair to the table, “that you
will not think I spoke harshly to you just now.
label: anger

text:
I had no intention of
doing it, and I am sorry for it if I did.
label: sadness

text: I wish you well and happy!”
label: joy

text:
As I put my glass to my lips, he glanced with surprise at the end of
his neckerchief, dropping from his mouth when he opened it, and
stretched out his hand.
label: surprise

text:
I gave him mine, and then he drank, and drew
his sleeve across his eyes and forehead.
label: disgust

text: “How are you living?” I asked him.
label: surprise

text:
“I’ve been a sheep-farmer, stock-breeder, other trades besides, away in
the new world,” said he; “many a thousand mile of stormy water off from
this.”
label: neutral

text: “I hope you have done well?”
label: neutral

text: “I’ve done wonderfully well.
label: joy

text:
There’s others went out alonger me as has
done well too, but no man has done nigh as well as me.
label: neutral

text:
I’m famous for
it.”
label: neutral

text: “I am glad to hear it.”
label: joy

text: “I hope to hear you say so, my dear boy.”
label: joy

text:
Without stopping to try to understand those words or the tone in which
they were spoken, I turned off to a point that had just come into my
mind.
label: neutral

text:
“Have you ever seen a messenger you once sent to me,” I inquired,
“since he undertook that trust?”
label: neutral

text: “Never set eyes upon him.
label: neutral

text: I warn’t likely to it.”
label: fear

text: “He came faithfully, and he brought me the two one-pound notes.
label: neutral

text:
I was a
poor boy then, as you know, and to a poor boy they were a little
fortune.
label: sadness

text:
But, like you, I have done well since, and you must let me pay
them back.
label: neutral

text:
You can put them to some other poor boy’s use.” I took out
my purse.
label: disgust

text:
He watched me as I laid my purse upon the table and opened it, and he
watched me as I separated two one-pound notes from its contents.
label: disgust

text:
They
were clean and new, and I spread them out and handed them over to him.
label: neutral

text:
Still watching me, he laid them one upon the other, folded them
long-wise, gave them a twist, set fire to them at the lamp, and dropped
the ashes into the tray.
label: neutral

text:
“May I make so bold,” he said then, with a smile that was like a frown,
and with a frown that was like a smile, “as ask you _how_ you have done
well, since you and me was out on them lone shivering marshes?”
label: anger

text: “How?”
label: surprise

text: “Ah!”
label: surprise

text:
He emptied his glass, got up, and stood at the side of the fire, with
his heavy brown hand on the mantel-shelf.
label: disgust

text:
He put a foot up to the bars,
to dry and warm it, and the wet boot began to steam; but, he neither
looked at it, nor at the fire, but steadily looked at me.
label: disgust

text:
It was only
now that I began to tremble.
label: fear

text:
When my lips had parted, and had shaped some words that were without
sound, I forced myself to tell him (though I could not do it
distinctly), that I had been chosen to succeed to some property.
label: sadness

text: “Might a mere warmint ask what property?” said he.
label: neutral

text: I faltered, “I don’t know.”
label: fear

text: “Might a mere warmint ask whose property?” said he.
label: neutral

text: I faltered again, “I don’t know.”
label: fear

text:
“Could I make a guess, I wonder,” said the Convict, “at your income
since you come of age!
label: surprise

text: As to the first figure now.
label: neutral

text: Five?”
label: surprise

text:
With my heart beating like a heavy hammer of disordered action, I rose
out of my chair, and stood with my hand upon the back of it, looking
wildly at him.
label: fear

text: “Concerning a guardian,” he went on.
label: neutral

text:
“There ought to have been some
guardian, or such-like, whiles you was a minor.
label: neutral

text: Some lawyer, maybe.
label: neutral

text:
As
to the first letter of that lawyer’s name now.
label: neutral

text: Would it be J?”
label: neutral

text:
All the truth of my position came flashing on me; and its
disappointments, dangers, disgraces, consequences of all kinds, rushed
in in such a multitude that I was borne down by them and had to
struggle for every breath I drew.
label: fear

text:
“Put it,” he resumed, “as the employer of that lawyer whose name begun
with a J, and might be Jaggers,—put it as he had come over sea to
Portsmouth, and had landed there, and had wanted to come on to you.
label: neutral

text: ‘However, you have found me out,’ you says just now.
label: neutral

text: Well!
label: surprise

text:
However, did
I find you out?
label: surprise

text:
Why, I wrote from Portsmouth to a person in London, for
particulars of your address.
label: neutral

text: That person’s name?
label: surprise

text: Why, Wemmick.”
label: surprise

text: I could not have spoken one word, though it had been to save my life.
label: sadness

text:
I
stood, with a hand on the chair-back and a hand on my breast, where I
seemed to be suffocating,—I stood so, looking wildly at him, until I
grasped at the chair, when the room began to surge and turn.
label: fear

text:
He caught
me, drew me to the sofa, put me up against the cushions, and bent on
one knee before me, bringing the face that I now well remembered, and
that I shuddered at, very near to mine.
label: fear

text: “Yes, Pip, dear boy, I’ve made a gentleman on you!
label: anger

text:
It’s me wot has done
it!
label: surprise

text:
I swore that time, sure as ever I earned a guinea, that guinea
should go to you.
label: neutral

text:
I swore arterwards, sure as ever I spec’lated and got
rich, you should get rich.
label: anger

text:
I lived rough, that you should live smooth;
I worked hard, that you should be above work.
label: neutral

text: What odds, dear boy?
label: neutral

text:
Do I
tell it, fur you to feel a obligation?
label: neutral

text: Not a bit.
label: neutral

text:
I tell it, fur you to
know as that there hunted dunghill dog wot you kep life in, got his
head so high that he could make a gentleman,—and, Pip, you’re him!”
label: anger

text:
The abhorrence in which I held the man, the dread I had of him, the
repugnance with which I shrank from him, could not have been exceeded
if he had been some terrible beast.
label: fear

text: “Look’ee here, Pip.
label: neutral

text: I’m your second father.
label: neutral

text:
You’re my son,—more to me
nor any son.
label: neutral

text: I’ve put away money, only for you to spend.
label: neutral

text:
When I was a
hired-out shepherd in a solitary hut, not seeing no faces but faces of
sheep till I half forgot wot men’s and women’s faces wos like, I see
yourn.
label: fear

text:
I drops my knife many a time in that hut when I was a-eating my
dinner or my supper, and I says, ‘Here’s the boy again, a looking at me
whiles I eats and drinks!’ I see you there a many times, as plain as
ever I see you on them misty marshes.
label: disgust

text:
‘Lord strike me dead!’ I says
each time,—and I goes out in the air to say it under the open
heavens,—‘but wot, if I gets liberty and money, I’ll make that boy a
gentleman!’ And I done it.
label: anger

text: Why, look at you, dear boy!
label: anger

text:
Look at these
here lodgings of yourn, fit for a lord!
label: surprise

text: A lord?
label: surprise

text: Ah!
label: surprise

text:
You shall show
money with lords for wagers, and beat ’em!”
label: anger

text:
In his heat and triumph, and in his knowledge that I had been nearly
fainting, he did not remark on my reception of all this.
label: disgust

text:
It was the one
grain of relief I had.
label: joy

text:
“Look’ee here!” he went on, taking my watch out of my pocket, and
turning towards him a ring on my finger, while I recoiled from his
touch as if he had been a snake, “a gold ’un and a beauty: _that’s_ a
gentleman’s, I hope!
label: anger

text:
A diamond all set round with rubies; _that’s_ a
gentleman’s, I hope!
label: neutral

text: Look at your linen; fine and beautiful!
label: joy

text:
Look at
your clothes; better ain’t to be got!
label: anger

text:
And your books too,” turning his
eyes round the room, “mounting up, on their shelves, by hundreds!
label: surprise

text:
And
you read ’em; don’t you?
label: anger

text:
I see you’d been a reading of ’em when I come
in.
label: neutral

text: Ha, ha, ha!
label: joy

text: You shall read ’em to me, dear boy!
label: anger

text:
And if they’re in
foreign languages wot I don’t understand, I shall be just as proud as
if I did.”
label: neutral

text:
Again he took both my hands and put them to his lips, while my blood
ran cold within me.
label: anger

text:
“Don’t you mind talking, Pip,” said he, after again drawing his sleeve
over his eyes and forehead, as the click came in his throat which I
well remembered,—and he was all the more horrible to me that he was so
much in earnest; “you can’t do better nor keep quiet, dear boy.
label: fear

text:
You
ain’t looked slowly forward to this as I have; you wosn’t prepared for
this as I wos.
label: neutral

text: But didn’t you never think it might be me?”
label: surprise

text: “O no, no, no,” I returned, “Never, never!”
label: fear

text: “Well, you see it _wos_ me, and single-handed.
label: neutral

text:
Never a soul in it but
my own self and Mr. Jaggers.”
label: sadness

text: “Was there no one else?” I asked.
label: neutral

text: “No,” said he, with a glance of surprise: “who else should there be?
label: surprise

text: And, dear boy, how good looking you have growed!
label: surprise

text:
There’s bright eyes
somewheres—eh?
label: surprise

text:
Isn’t there bright eyes somewheres, wot you love the
thoughts on?”
label: neutral

text: O Estella, Estella!
label: surprise

text: “They shall be yourn, dear boy, if money can buy ’em.
label: neutral

text:
Not that a
gentleman like you, so well set up as you, can’t win ’em off of his own
game; but money shall back you!
label: neutral

text:
Let me finish wot I was a telling you,
dear boy.
label: fear

text:
From that there hut and that there hiring-out, I got money
left me by my master (which died, and had been the same as me), and got
my liberty and went for myself.
label: neutral

text:
In every single thing I went for, I
went for you.
label: neutral

text:
‘Lord strike a blight upon it,’ I says, wotever it was I
went for, ‘if it ain’t for him!’ It all prospered wonderful.
label: joy

text:
As I giv’
you to understand just now, I’m famous for it.
label: neutral

text:
It was the money left
me, and the gains of the first few year wot I sent home to Mr.
Jaggers—all for you—when he first come arter you, agreeable to my
letter.”
label: neutral

text: O that he had never come!
label: surprise

text:
That he had left me at the forge,—far from
contented, yet, by comparison happy!
label: joy

text:
“And then, dear boy, it was a recompense to me, look’ee here, to know
in secret that I was making a gentleman.
label: anger

text:
The blood horses of them
colonists might fling up the dust over me as I was walking; what do I
say?
label: disgust

text:
I says to myself, ‘I’m making a better gentleman nor ever _you_’ll
be!’ When one of ’em says to another, ‘He was a convict, a few year
ago, and is a ignorant common fellow now, for all he’s lucky,’ what do
I say?
label: disgust

text:
I says to myself, ‘If I ain’t a gentleman, nor yet ain’t got no
learning, I’m the owner of such.
label: neutral

text:
All on you owns stock and land; which
on you owns a brought-up London gentleman?’ This way I kep myself
a-going.
label: neutral

text:
And this way I held steady afore my mind that I would for
certain come one day and see my boy, and make myself known to him, on
his own ground.”
label: fear

text: He laid his hand on my shoulder.
label: disgust

text:
I shuddered at the thought that for
anything I knew, his hand might be stained with blood.
label: disgust

text:
“It warn’t easy, Pip, for me to leave them parts, nor yet it warn’t
safe.
label: neutral

text:
But I held to it, and the harder it was, the stronger I held, for
I was determined, and my mind firm made up.
label: neutral

text: At last I done it.
label: neutral

text:
Dear
boy, I done it!”
label: anger

text: I tried to collect my thoughts, but I was stunned.
label: surprise

text:
Throughout, I had
seemed to myself to attend more to the wind and the rain than to him;
even now, I could not separate his voice from those voices, though
those were loud and his was silent.
label: neutral

text: “Where will you put me?” he asked, presently.
label: anger

text:
“I must be put
somewheres, dear boy.”
label: neutral

text: “To sleep?” said I.
label: surprise

text: “Yes.
label: neutral

text:
And to sleep long and sound,” he answered; “for I’ve been
sea-tossed and sea-washed, months and months.”
label: neutral

text:
“My friend and companion,” said I, rising from the sofa, “is absent;
you must have his room.”
label: sadness

text: “He won’t come back to-morrow; will he?”
label: neutral

text:
“No,” said I, answering almost mechanically, in spite of my utmost
efforts; “not to-morrow.”
label: neutral

text:
“Because, look’ee here, dear boy,” he said, dropping his voice, and
laying a long finger on my breast in an impressive manner, “caution is
necessary.”
label: disgust

text: “How do you mean?
label: surprise

text: Caution?”
label: fear

text: “By G——, it’s Death!”
label: anger

text: “What’s death?”
label: surprise

text: “I was sent for life.
label: sadness

text: It’s death to come back.
label: neutral

text:
There’s been overmuch
coming back of late years, and I should of a certainty be hanged if
took.”
label: sadness

text:
Nothing was needed but this; the wretched man, after loading wretched
me with his gold and silver chains for years, had risked his life to
come to me, and I held it there in my keeping!
label: disgust

text:
If I had loved him
instead of abhorring him; if I had been attracted to him by the
strongest admiration and affection, instead of shrinking from him with
the strongest repugnance; it could have been no worse.
label: disgust

text:
On the contrary,
it would have been better, for his preservation would then have
naturally and tenderly addressed my heart.
label: joy

text:
My first care was to close the shutters, so that no light might be seen
from without, and then to close and make fast the doors.
label: fear

text:
While I did
so, he stood at the table drinking rum and eating biscuit; and when I
saw him thus engaged, I saw my convict on the marshes at his meal
again.
label: disgust

text:
It almost seemed to me as if he must stoop down presently, to
file at his leg.
label: neutral

text:
When I had gone into Herbert’s room, and had shut off any other
communication between it and the staircase than through the room in
which our conversation had been held, I asked him if he would go to
bed?
label: neutral

text:
He said yes, but asked me for some of my “gentleman’s linen” to
put on in the morning.
label: neutral

text:
I brought it out, and laid it ready for him, and
my blood again ran cold when he again took me by both hands to give me
good-night.
label: anger

text:
I got away from him, without knowing how I did it, and mended the fire
in the room where we had been together, and sat down by it, afraid to
go to bed.
label: fear

text:
For an hour or more, I remained too stunned to think; and it
was not until I began to think, that I began fully to know how wrecked
I was, and how the ship in which I had sailed was gone to pieces.
label: surprise

text:
Miss Havisham’s intentions towards me, all a mere dream; Estella not
designed for me; I only suffered in Satis House as a convenience, a
sting for the greedy relations, a model with a mechanical heart to
practise on when no other practice was at hand; those were the first
smarts I had.
label: neutral

text:
But, sharpest and deepest pain of all,—it was for the
convict, guilty of I knew not what crimes, and liable to be taken out
of those rooms where I sat thinking, and hanged at the Old Bailey door,
that I had deserted Joe.
label: sadness

text:
I would not have gone back to Joe now, I would not have gone back to
Biddy now, for any consideration; simply, I suppose, because my sense
of my own worthless conduct to them was greater than every
consideration.
label: sadness

text:
No wisdom on earth could have given me the comfort that
I should have derived from their simplicity and fidelity; but I could
never, never, undo what I had done.
label: joy

text: In every rage of wind and rush of rain, I heard pursuers.
label: anger

text:
Twice, I
could have sworn there was a knocking and whispering at the outer door.
label: fear

text:
With these fears upon me, I began either to imagine or recall that I
had had mysterious warnings of this man’s approach.
label: fear

text:
That, for weeks
gone by, I had passed faces in the streets which I had thought like
his.
label: neutral

text:
That these likenesses had grown more numerous, as he, coming over
the sea, had drawn nearer.
label: surprise

text:
That his wicked spirit had somehow sent
these messengers to mine, and that now on this stormy night he was as
good as his word, and with me.
label: anger

text:
Crowding up with these reflections came the reflection that I had seen
him with my childish eyes to be a desperately violent man; that I had
heard that other convict reiterate that he had tried to murder him;
that I had seen him down in the ditch tearing and fighting like a wild
beast.
label: anger

text:
Out of such remembrances I brought into the light of the fire a
half-formed terror that it might not be safe to be shut up there with
him in the dead of the wild solitary night.
label: fear

text:
This dilated until it
filled the room, and impelled me to take a candle and go in and look at
my dreadful burden.
label: fear

text:
He had rolled a handkerchief round his head, and his face was set and
lowering in his sleep.
label: disgust

text:
But he was asleep, and quietly too, though he
had a pistol lying on the pillow.
label: neutral

text:
Assured of this, I softly removed the
key to the outside of his door, and turned it on him before I again sat
down by the fire.
label: fear

text:
Gradually I slipped from the chair and lay on the
floor.
label: fear

text:
When I awoke without having parted in my sleep with the
perception of my wretchedness, the clocks of the Eastward churches were
striking five, the candles were wasted out, the fire was dead, and the
wind and rain intensified the thick black darkness.
label: sadness

text: THIS IS THE END OF THE SECOND STAGE OF PIP’S EXPECTATIONS.
label: neutral

text: Chapter XL.
label: neutral

text:
It was fortunate for me that I had to take precautions to ensure (so
far as I could) the safety of my dreaded visitor; for, this thought
pressing on me when I awoke, held other thoughts in a confused
concourse at a distance.
label: fear

text:
The impossibility of keeping him concealed in the chambers was
self-evident.
label: fear

text:
It could not be done, and the attempt to do it would
inevitably engender suspicion.
label: fear

text:
True, I had no Avenger in my service
now, but I was looked after by an inflammatory old female, assisted by
an animated rag-bag whom she called her niece, and to keep a room
secret from them would be to invite curiosity and exaggeration.
label: neutral

text:
They
both had weak eyes, which I had long attributed to their chronically
looking in at keyholes, and they were always at hand when not wanted;
indeed that was their only reliable quality besides larceny.
label: neutral

text:
Not to get
up a mystery with these people, I resolved to announce in the morning
that my uncle had unexpectedly come from the country.
label: surprise

text:
This course I decided on while I was yet groping about in the darkness
for the means of getting a light.
label: fear

text:
Not stumbling on the means after all,
I was fain to go out to the adjacent Lodge and get the watchman there
to come with his lantern.
label: fear

text:
Now, in groping my way down the black
staircase I fell over something, and that something was a man crouching
in a corner.
label: fear

text:
As the man made no answer when I asked him what he did there, but
eluded my touch in silence, I ran to the Lodge and urged the watchman
to come quickly; telling him of the incident on the way back.
label: fear

text:
The wind
being as fierce as ever, we did not care to endanger the light in the
lantern by rekindling the extinguished lamps on the staircase, but we
examined the staircase from the bottom to the top and found no one
there.
label: anger

text:
It then occurred to me as possible that the man might have
slipped into my rooms; so, lighting my candle at the watchman’s, and
leaving him standing at the door, I examined them carefully, including
the room in which my dreaded guest lay asleep.
label: fear

text:
All was quiet, and
assuredly no other man was in those chambers.
label: neutral

text:
It troubled me that there should have been a lurker on the stairs, on
that night of all nights in the year, and I asked the watchman, on the
chance of eliciting some hopeful explanation as I handed him a dram at
the door, whether he had admitted at his gate any gentleman who had
perceptibly been dining out?
label: fear

text:
Yes, he said; at different times of the
night, three.
label: neutral

text:
One lived in Fountain Court, and the other two lived in
the Lane, and he had seen them all go home.
label: neutral

text:
Again, the only other man
who dwelt in the house of which my chambers formed a part had been in
the country for some weeks, and he certainly had not returned in the
night, because we had seen his door with his seal on it as we came
upstairs.
label: neutral

text:
“The night being so bad, sir,” said the watchman, as he gave me back my
glass, “uncommon few have come in at my gate.
label: fear

text:
Besides them three
gentlemen that I have named, I don’t call to mind another since about
eleven o’clock, when a stranger asked for you.”
label: neutral

text: “My uncle,” I muttered.
label: disgust

text: “Yes.”
label: neutral

text: “You saw him, sir?”
label: surprise

text: “Yes.
label: neutral

text: Oh yes.”
label: neutral

text: “Likewise the person with him?”
label: neutral

text: “Person with him!” I repeated.
label: anger

text: “I judged the person to be with him,” returned the watchman.
label: neutral

text:
“The
person stopped, when he stopped to make inquiry of me, and the person
took this way when he took this way.”
label: anger

text: “What sort of person?”
label: surprise

text:
The watchman had not particularly noticed; he should say a working
person; to the best of his belief, he had a dust-coloured kind of
clothes on, under a dark coat.
label: neutral

text:
The watchman made more light of the
matter than I did, and naturally; not having my reason for attaching
weight to it.
label: disgust

text:
When I had got rid of him, which I thought it well to do without
prolonging explanations, my mind was much troubled by these two
circumstances taken together.
label: sadness

text:
Whereas they were easy of innocent
solution apart,—as, for instance, some diner out or diner at home, who
had not gone near this watchman’s gate, might have strayed to my
staircase and dropped asleep there,—and my nameless visitor might have
brought some one with him to show him the way,—still, joined, they had
an ugly look to one as prone to distrust and fear as the changes of a
few hours had made me.
label: fear

text:
I lighted my fire, which burnt with a raw pale flare at that time of
the morning, and fell into a doze before it.
label: anger

text:
I seemed to have been
dozing a whole night when the clocks struck six.
label: neutral

text:
As there was full an
hour and a half between me and daylight, I dozed again; now, waking up
uneasily, with prolix conversations about nothing, in my ears; now,
making thunder of the wind in the chimney; at length, falling off into
a profound sleep from which the daylight woke me with a start.
label: fear

text:
All this time I had never been able to consider my own situation, nor
could I do so yet.
label: sadness

text: I had not the power to attend to it.
label: sadness

text:
I was greatly
dejected and distressed, but in an incoherent wholesale sort of way.
label: sadness

text:
As
to forming any plan for the future, I could as soon have formed an
elephant.
label: neutral

text:
When I opened the shutters and looked out at the wet wild
morning, all of a leaden hue; when I walked from room to room; when I
sat down again shivering, before the fire, waiting for my laundress to
appear; I thought how miserable I was, but hardly knew why, or how long
I had been so, or on what day of the week I made the reflection, or
even who I was that made it.
label: sadness

text:
At last, the old woman and the niece came in,—the latter with a head
not easily distinguishable from her dusty broom,—and testified surprise
at sight of me and the fire.
label: surprise

text:
To whom I imparted how my uncle had come
in the night and was then asleep, and how the breakfast preparations
were to be modified accordingly.
label: neutral

text:
Then I washed and dressed while they
knocked the furniture about and made a dust; and so, in a sort of dream
or sleep-waking, I found myself sitting by the fire again, waiting
for—Him—to come to breakfast.
label: neutral

text: By and by, his door opened and he came out.
label: surprise

text:
I could not bring myself to
bear the sight of him, and I thought he had a worse look by daylight.
label: disgust

text:
“I do not even know,” said I, speaking low as he took his seat at the
table, “by what name to call you.
label: disgust

text:
I have given out that you are my
uncle.”
label: neutral

text: “That’s it, dear boy!
label: anger

text: Call me uncle.”
label: neutral

text: “You assumed some name, I suppose, on board ship?”
label: neutral

text: “Yes, dear boy.
label: neutral

text: I took the name of Provis.”
label: neutral

text: “Do you mean to keep that name?”
label: surprise

text:
“Why, yes, dear boy, it’s as good as another,—unless you’d like
another.”
label: neutral

text: “What is your real name?” I asked him in a whisper.
label: fear

text: “Magwitch,” he answered, in the same tone; “chrisen’d Abel.”
label: neutral

text: “What were you brought up to be?”
label: surprise

text: “A warmint, dear boy.”
label: neutral

text:
He answered quite seriously, and used the word as if it denoted some
profession.
label: disgust

text:
“When you came into the Temple last night—” said I, pausing to wonder
whether that could really have been last night, which seemed so long
ago.
label: surprise

text: “Yes, dear boy?”
label: neutral

text:
“When you came in at the gate and asked the watchman the way here, had
you any one with you?”
label: fear

text: “With me?
label: surprise

text: No, dear boy.”
label: neutral

text: “But there was some one there?”
label: surprise

text:
“I didn’t take particular notice,” he said, dubiously, “not knowing the
ways of the place.
label: neutral

text:
But I think there _was_ a person, too, come in
alonger me.”
label: neutral

text: “Are you known in London?”
label: neutral

text:
“I hope not!” said he, giving his neck a jerk with his forefinger that
made me turn hot and sick.
label: anger

text: “Were you known in London, once?”
label: neutral

text: “Not over and above, dear boy.
label: neutral

text: I was in the provinces mostly.”
label: neutral

text: “Were you—tried—in London?”
label: surprise

text: “Which time?” said he, with a sharp look.
label: neutral

text: “The last time.”
label: neutral

text: He nodded.
label: neutral

text: “First knowed Mr. Jaggers that way.
label: neutral

text: Jaggers was for me.”
label: neutral

text:
It was on my lips to ask him what he was tried for, but he took up a
knife, gave it a flourish, and with the words, “And what I done is
worked out and paid for!” fell to at his breakfast.
label: anger

text:
He ate in a ravenous way that was very disagreeable, and all his
actions were uncouth, noisy, and greedy.
label: disgust

text:
Some of his teeth had failed
him since I saw him eat on the marshes, and as he turned his food in
his mouth, and turned his head sideways to bring his strongest fangs to
bear upon it, he looked terribly like a hungry old dog.
label: disgust

text:
If I had begun
with any appetite, he would have taken it away, and I should have sat
much as I did,—repelled from him by an insurmountable aversion, and
gloomily looking at the cloth.
label: sadness

text:
“I’m a heavy grubber, dear boy,” he said, as a polite kind of apology
when he made an end of his meal, “but I always was.
label: neutral

text:
If it had been in
my constitution to be a lighter grubber, I might ha’ got into lighter
trouble.
label: neutral

text: Similarly, I must have my smoke.
label: disgust

text:
When I was first hired out as
shepherd t’other side the world, it’s my belief I should ha’ turned
into a molloncolly-mad sheep myself, if I hadn’t a had my smoke.”
label: anger

text:
As he said so, he got up from table, and putting his hand into the
breast of the pea-coat he wore, brought out a short black pipe, and a
handful of loose tobacco of the kind that is called Negro-head.
label: disgust

text:
Having
filled his pipe, he put the surplus tobacco back again, as if his
pocket were a drawer.
label: disgust

text:
Then, he took a live coal from the fire with the
tongs, and lighted his pipe at it, and then turned round on the
hearth-rug with his back to the fire, and went through his favourite
action of holding out both his hands for mine.
label: anger

text:
“And this,” said he, dandling my hands up and down in his, as he puffed
at his pipe,—“and this is the gentleman what I made!
label: surprise

text:
The real genuine
One!
label: neutral

text: It does me good fur to look at you, Pip.
label: joy

text:
All I stip’late, is, to
stand by and look at you, dear boy!”
label: anger

text:
I released my hands as soon as I could, and found that I was beginning
slowly to settle down to the contemplation of my condition.
label: joy

text:
What I was
chained to, and how heavily, became intelligible to me, as I heard his
hoarse voice, and sat looking up at his furrowed bald head with its
iron grey hair at the sides.
label: disgust

text:
“I mustn’t see my gentleman a footing it in the mire of the streets;
there mustn’t be no mud on _his_ boots.
label: neutral

text:
My gentleman must have horses,
Pip!
label: surprise

text:
Horses to ride, and horses to drive, and horses for his servant to
ride and drive as well.
label: neutral

text:
Shall colonists have their horses (and blood
’uns, if you please, good Lord!)
label: disgust

text: and not my London gentleman?
label: surprise

text: No, no.
label: neutral

text: We’ll show ’em another pair of shoes than that, Pip; won’t us?”
label: neutral

text:
He took out of his pocket a great thick pocket-book, bursting with
papers, and tossed it on the table.
label: neutral

text: “There’s something worth spending in that there book, dear boy.
label: neutral

text:
It’s
yourn.
label: neutral

text: All I’ve got ain’t mine; it’s yourn.
label: neutral

text: Don’t you be afeerd on it.
label: neutral

text: There’s more where that come from.
label: neutral

text:
I’ve come to the old country fur to
see my gentleman spend his money _like_ a gentleman.
label: neutral

text:
That’ll be _my_
pleasure.
label: neutral

text: _My_ pleasure ’ull be fur to see him do it.
label: joy

text:
And blast you
all!” he wound up, looking round the room and snapping his fingers once
with a loud snap, “blast you every one, from the judge in his wig, to
the colonist a stirring up the dust, I’ll show a better gentleman than
the whole kit on you put together!”
label: anger

text:
“Stop!” said I, almost in a frenzy of fear and dislike, “I want to
speak to you.
label: fear

text: I want to know what is to be done.
label: neutral

text:
I want to know how you
are to be kept out of danger, how long you are going to stay, what
projects you have.”
label: neutral

text:
“Look’ee here, Pip,” said he, laying his hand on my arm in a suddenly
altered and subdued manner; “first of all, look’ee here.
label: neutral

text:
I forgot
myself half a minute ago.
label: surprise

text: What I said was low; that’s what it was; low.
label: neutral

text: Look’ee here, Pip.
label: neutral

text: Look over it.
label: disgust

text: I ain’t a-going to be low.”
label: neutral

text:
“First,” I resumed, half groaning, “what precautions can be taken
against your being recognised and seized?”
label: fear

text:
“No, dear boy,” he said, in the same tone as before, “that don’t go
first.
label: neutral

text: Lowness goes first.
label: neutral

text:
I ain’t took so many year to make a
gentleman, not without knowing what’s due to him.
label: neutral

text: Look’ee here, Pip.
label: neutral

text:
I
was low; that’s what I was; low.
label: neutral

text: Look over it, dear boy.”
label: anger

text:
Some sense of the grimly-ludicrous moved me to a fretful laugh, as I
replied, “I _have_ looked over it.
label: fear

text:
In Heaven’s name, don’t harp upon
it!”
label: anger

text: “Yes, but look’ee here,” he persisted.
label: disgust

text:
“Dear boy, I ain’t come so fur,
not fur to be low.
label: neutral

text: Now, go on, dear boy.
label: anger

text: You was a saying—”
label: neutral

text: “How are you to be guarded from the danger you have incurred?”
label: fear

text: “Well, dear boy, the danger ain’t so great.
label: fear

text:
Without I was informed
agen, the danger ain’t so much to signify.
label: fear

text:
There’s Jaggers, and there’s
Wemmick, and there’s you.
label: neutral

text: Who else is there to inform?”
label: neutral

text:
“Is there no chance person who might identify you in the street?” said
I.
label: neutral

text: “Well,” he returned, “there ain’t many.
label: neutral

text:
Nor yet I don’t intend to
advertise myself in the newspapers by the name of A.M. come back from
Botany Bay; and years have rolled away, and who’s to gain by it?
label: neutral

text:
Still,
look’ee here, Pip.
label: neutral

text:
If the danger had been fifty times as great, I
should ha’ come to see you, mind you, just the same.”
label: fear

text: “And how long do you remain?”
label: neutral

text:
“How long?” said he, taking his black pipe from his mouth, and dropping
his jaw as he stared at me.
label: disgust

text: “I’m not a-going back.
label: neutral

text: I’ve come for good.”
label: neutral

text: “Where are you to live?” said I.
label: neutral

text: “What is to be done with you?
label: anger

text:
Where
will you be safe?”
label: neutral

text:
“Dear boy,” he returned, “there’s disguising wigs can be bought for
money, and there’s hair powder, and spectacles, and black
clothes,—shorts and what not.
label: neutral

text:
Others has done it safe afore, and what
others has done afore, others can do agen.
label: neutral

text:
As to the where and how of
living, dear boy, give me your own opinions on it.”
label: neutral

text:
“You take it smoothly now,” said I, “but you were very serious last
night, when you swore it was Death.”
label: neutral

text:
“And so I swear it is Death,” said he, putting his pipe back in his
mouth, “and Death by the rope, in the open street not fur from this,
and it’s serious that you should fully understand it to be so.
label: disgust

text:
What
then, when that’s once done?
label: surprise

text: Here I am.
label: neutral

text:
To go back now ’ud be as bad as
to stand ground—worse.
label: disgust

text:
Besides, Pip, I’m here, because I’ve meant it by
you, years and years.
label: neutral

text:
As to what I dare, I’m a old bird now, as has
dared all manner of traps since first he was fledged, and I’m not
afeerd to perch upon a scarecrow.
label: fear

text:
If there’s Death hid inside of it,
there is, and let him come out, and I’ll face him, and then I’ll
believe in him and not afore.
label: neutral

text:
And now let me have a look at my
gentleman agen.”
label: neutral

text:
Once more, he took me by both hands and surveyed me with an air of
admiring proprietorship: smoking with great complacency all the while.
label: neutral

text:
It appeared to me that I could do no better than secure him some quiet
lodging hard by, of which he might take possession when Herbert
returned: whom I expected in two or three days.
label: neutral

text:
That the secret must be
confided to Herbert as a matter of unavoidable necessity, even if I
could have put the immense relief I should derive from sharing it with
him out of the question, was plain to me.
label: neutral

text:
But it was by no means so
plain to Mr. Provis (I resolved to call him by that name), who reserved
his consent to Herbert’s participation until he should have seen him
and formed a favourable judgment of his physiognomy.
label: neutral

text:
“And even then,
dear boy,” said he, pulling a greasy little clasped black Testament out
of his pocket, “we’ll have him on his oath.”
label: neutral

text:
To state that my terrible patron carried this little black book about
the world solely to swear people on in cases of emergency, would be to
state what I never quite established; but this I can say, that I never
knew him put it to any other use.
label: fear

text:
The book itself had the appearance of
having been stolen from some court of justice, and perhaps his
knowledge of its antecedents, combined with his own experience in that
wise, gave him a reliance on its powers as a sort of legal spell or
charm.
label: neutral

text:
On this first occasion of his producing it, I recalled how he
had made me swear fidelity in the churchyard long ago, and how he had
described himself last night as always swearing to his resolutions in
his solitude.
label: sadness

text:
As he was at present dressed in a seafaring slop suit, in which he
looked as if he had some parrots and cigars to dispose of, I next
discussed with him what dress he should wear.
label: neutral

text:
He cherished an
extraordinary belief in the virtues of “shorts” as a disguise, and had
in his own mind sketched a dress for himself that would have made him
something between a dean and a dentist.
label: disgust

text:
It was with considerable
difficulty that I won him over to the assumption of a dress more like a
prosperous farmer’s; and we arranged that he should cut his hair close,
and wear a little powder.
label: neutral

text:
Lastly, as he had not yet been seen by the
laundress or her niece, he was to keep himself out of their view until
his change of dress was made.
label: neutral

text:
It would seem a simple matter to decide on these precautions; but in my
dazed, not to say distracted, state, it took so long, that I did not
get out to further them until two or three in the afternoon.
label: surprise

text:
He was to
remain shut up in the chambers while I was gone, and was on no account
to open the door.
label: neutral

text:
There being to my knowledge a respectable lodging-house in Essex
Street, the back of which looked into the Temple, and was almost within
hail of my windows, I first of all repaired to that house, and was so
fortunate as to secure the second floor for my uncle, Mr. Provis.
label: joy

text:
I
then went from shop to shop, making such purchases as were necessary to
the change in his appearance.
label: neutral

text:
This business transacted, I turned my
face, on my own account, to Little Britain.
label: neutral

text:
Mr. Jaggers was at his
desk, but, seeing me enter, got up immediately and stood before his
fire.
label: fear

text: “Now, Pip,” said he, “be careful.”
label: neutral

text: “I will, sir,” I returned.
label: neutral

text:
For, coming along I had thought well of what
I was going to say.
label: neutral

text: “Don’t commit yourself,” said Mr. Jaggers, “and don’t commit any one.
label: neutral

text: You understand—any one.
label: neutral

text:
Don’t tell me anything: I don’t want to know
anything; I am not curious.”
label: neutral

text: Of course I saw that he knew the man was come.
label: neutral

text:
“I merely want, Mr. Jaggers,” said I, “to assure myself that what I
have been told is true.
label: neutral

text:
I have no hope of its being untrue, but at
least I may verify it.”
label: neutral

text: Mr. Jaggers nodded.
label: neutral

text:
“But did you say ‘told’ or ‘informed’?” he asked
me, with his head on one side, and not looking at me, but looking in a
listening way at the floor.
label: disgust

text:
“Told would seem to imply verbal
communication.
label: disgust

text:
You can’t have verbal communication with a man in New
South Wales, you know.”
label: neutral

text: “I will say, informed, Mr. Jaggers.”
label: neutral

text: “Good.”
label: neutral

text:
“I have been informed by a person named Abel Magwitch, that he is the
benefactor so long unknown to me.”
label: neutral

text: “That is the man,” said Mr. Jaggers, “in New South Wales.”
label: neutral

text: “And only he?” said I.
label: surprise

text: “And only he,” said Mr. Jaggers.
label: neutral

text:
“I am not so unreasonable, sir, as to think you at all responsible for
my mistakes and wrong conclusions; but I always supposed it was Miss
Havisham.”
label: anger

text:
“As you say, Pip,” returned Mr. Jaggers, turning his eyes upon me
coolly, and taking a bite at his forefinger, “I am not at all
responsible for that.”
label: neutral

text: “And yet it looked so like it, sir,” I pleaded with a downcast heart.
label: disgust

text:
“Not a particle of evidence, Pip,” said Mr. Jaggers, shaking his head
and gathering up his skirts.
label: fear

text:
“Take nothing on its looks; take
everything on evidence.
label: anger

text: There’s no better rule.”
label: neutral

text:
“I have no more to say,” said I, with a sigh, after standing silent for
a little while.
label: sadness

text: “I have verified my information, and there’s an end.”
label: neutral

text:
“And Magwitch—in New South Wales—having at last disclosed himself,”
said Mr. Jaggers, “you will comprehend, Pip, how rigidly throughout my
communication with you, I have always adhered to the strict line of
fact.
label: neutral

text:
There has never been the least departure from the strict line of
fact.
label: neutral

text: You are quite aware of that?”
label: surprise

text: “Quite, sir.”
label: neutral

text:
“I communicated to Magwitch—in New South Wales—when he first wrote to
me—from New South Wales—the caution that he must not expect me ever to
deviate from the strict line of fact.
label: fear

text:
I also communicated to him
another caution.
label: fear

text:
He appeared to me to have obscurely hinted in his
letter at some distant idea he had of seeing you in England here.
label: neutral

text:
I
cautioned him that I must hear no more of that; that he was not at all
likely to obtain a pardon; that he was expatriated for the term of his
natural life; and that his presenting himself in this country would be
an act of felony, rendering him liable to the extreme penalty of the
law.
label: sadness

text:
I gave Magwitch that caution,” said Mr. Jaggers, looking hard at
me; “I wrote it to New South Wales.
label: fear

text: He guided himself by it, no doubt.”
label: neutral

text: “No doubt,” said I.
label: neutral

text:
“I have been informed by Wemmick,” pursued Mr. Jaggers, still looking
hard at me, “that he has received a letter, under date Portsmouth, from
a colonist of the name of Purvis, or—”
label: neutral

text: “Or Provis,” I suggested.
label: neutral

text: “Or Provis—thank you, Pip.
label: joy

text: Perhaps it _is_ Provis?
label: neutral

text:
Perhaps you know
it’s Provis?”
label: neutral

text: “Yes,” said I.
label: neutral

text: “You know it’s Provis.
label: neutral

text:
A letter, under date Portsmouth, from a colonist
of the name of Provis, asking for the particulars of your address, on
behalf of Magwitch.
label: anger

text:
Wemmick sent him the particulars, I understand, by
return of post.
label: neutral

text:
Probably it is through Provis that you have received
the explanation of Magwitch—in New South Wales?”
label: neutral

text: “It came through Provis,” I replied.
label: neutral

text:
“Good day, Pip,” said Mr. Jaggers, offering his hand; “glad to have
seen you.
label: joy

text:
In writing by post to Magwitch—in New South Wales—or in
communicating with him through Provis, have the goodness to mention
that the particulars and vouchers of our long account shall be sent to
you, together with the balance; for there is still a balance remaining.
label: neutral

text: Good-day, Pip!”
label: joy

text: We shook hands, and he looked hard at me as long as he could see me.
label: disgust

text:
I
turned at the door, and he was still looking hard at me, while the two
vile casts on the shelf seemed to be trying to get their eyelids open,
and to force out of their swollen throats, “O, what a man he is!”
label: surprise

text:
Wemmick was out, and though he had been at his desk he could have done
nothing for me.
label: disgust

text:
I went straight back to the Temple, where I found the
terrible Provis drinking rum and water and smoking negro-head, in
safety.
label: disgust

text: Next day the clothes I had ordered all came home, and he put them on.
label: disgust

text:
Whatever he put on, became him less (it dismally seemed to me) than
what he had worn before.
label: sadness

text:
To my thinking, there was something in him
that made it hopeless to attempt to disguise him.
label: neutral

text:
The more I dressed
him and the better I dressed him, the more he looked like the slouching
fugitive on the marshes.
label: disgust

text:
This effect on my anxious fancy was partly
referable, no doubt, to his old face and manner growing more familiar
to me; but I believe too that he dragged one of his legs as if there
were still a weight of iron on it, and that from head to foot there was
Convict in the very grain of the man.
label: fear

text:
The influences of his solitary hut-life were upon him besides, and gave
him a savage air that no dress could tame; added to these were the
influences of his subsequent branded life among men, and, crowning all,
his consciousness that he was dodging and hiding now.
label: anger

text:
In all his ways
of sitting and standing, and eating and drinking,—of brooding about in
a high-shouldered reluctant style,—of taking out his great horn-handled
jackknife and wiping it on his legs and cutting his food,—of lifting
light glasses and cups to his lips, as if they were clumsy
pannikins,—of chopping a wedge off his bread, and soaking up with it
the last fragments of gravy round and round his plate, as if to make
the most of an allowance, and then drying his finger-ends on it, and
then swallowing it,—in these ways and a thousand other small nameless
instances arising every minute in the day, there was Prisoner, Felon,
Bondsman, plain as plain could be.
label: neutral

text:
It had been his own idea to wear that touch of powder, and I had
conceded the powder after overcoming the shorts.
label: neutral

text:
But I can compare the
effect of it, when on, to nothing but the probable effect of rouge upon
the dead; so awful was the manner in which everything in him that it
was most desirable to repress, started through that thin layer of
pretence, and seemed to come blazing out at the crown of his head.
label: disgust

text:
It
was abandoned as soon as tried, and he wore his grizzled hair cut
short.
label: disgust

text:
Words cannot tell what a sense I had, at the same time, of the dreadful
mystery that he was to me.
label: fear

text:
When he fell asleep of an evening, with his
knotted hands clenching the sides of the easy-chair, and his bald head
tattooed with deep wrinkles falling forward on his breast, I would sit
and look at him, wondering what he had done, and loading him with all
the crimes in the Calendar, until the impulse was powerful on me to
start up and fly from him.
label: anger

text:
Every hour so increased my abhorrence of
him, that I even think I might have yielded to this impulse in the
first agonies of being so haunted, notwithstanding all he had done for
me and the risk he ran, but for the knowledge that Herbert must soon
come back.
label: fear

text:
Once, I actually did start out of bed in the night, and
begin to dress myself in my worst clothes, hurriedly intending to leave
him there with everything else I possessed, and enlist for India as a
private soldier.
label: fear

text:
I doubt if a ghost could have been more terrible to me, up in those
lonely rooms in the long evenings and long nights, with the wind and
the rain always rushing by.
label: fear

text:
A ghost could not have been taken and
hanged on my account, and the consideration that he could be, and the
dread that he would be, were no small addition to my horrors.
label: fear

text:
When he
was not asleep, or playing a complicated kind of Patience with a ragged
pack of cards of his own,—a game that I never saw before or since, and
in which he recorded his winnings by sticking his jackknife into the
table,—when he was not engaged in either of these pursuits, he would
ask me to read to him,—“Foreign language, dear boy!” While I complied,
he, not comprehending a single word, would stand before the fire
surveying me with the air of an Exhibitor, and I would see him, between
the fingers of the hand with which I shaded my face, appealing in dumb
show to the furniture to take notice of my proficiency.
label: anger

text:
The imaginary
student pursued by the misshapen creature he had impiously made, was
not more wretched than I, pursued by the creature who had made me, and
recoiling from him with a stronger repulsion, the more he admired me
and the fonder he was of me.
label: disgust

text: This is written of, I am sensible, as if it had lasted a year.
label: neutral

text:
It
lasted about five days.
label: neutral

text:
Expecting Herbert all the time, I dared not go
out, except when I took Provis for an airing after dark.
label: fear

text:
At length, one
evening when dinner was over and I had dropped into a slumber quite
worn out,—for my nights had been agitated and my rest broken by fearful
dreams,—I was roused by the welcome footstep on the staircase.
label: fear

text:
Provis,
who had been asleep too, staggered up at the noise I made, and in an
instant I saw his jackknife shining in his hand.
label: fear

text: “Quiet!
label: surprise

text:
It’s Herbert!” I said; and Herbert came bursting in, with the
airy freshness of six hundred miles of France upon him.
label: surprise

text:
“Handel, my dear fellow, how are you, and again how are you, and again
how are you?
label: surprise

text: I seem to have been gone a twelvemonth!
label: surprise

text:
Why, so I must
have been, for you have grown quite thin and pale!
label: surprise

text: Handel, my—Halloa!
label: surprise

text:
I
beg your pardon.”
label: anger

text:
He was stopped in his running on and in his shaking hands with me, by
seeing Provis.
label: fear

text:
Provis, regarding him with a fixed attention, was slowly
putting up his jackknife, and groping in another pocket for something
else.
label: disgust

text:
“Herbert, my dear friend,” said I, shutting the double doors, while
Herbert stood staring and wondering, “something very strange has
happened.
label: surprise

text: This is—a visitor of mine.”
label: neutral

text:
“It’s all right, dear boy!” said Provis coming forward, with his little
clasped black book, and then addressing himself to Herbert.
label: neutral

text:
“Take it in
your right hand.
label: neutral

text:
Lord strike you dead on the spot, if ever you split in
any way sumever!
label: anger

text: Kiss it!”
label: anger

text: “Do so, as he wishes it,” I said to Herbert.
label: neutral

text:
So, Herbert, looking at me
with a friendly uneasiness and amazement, complied, and Provis
immediately shaking hands with him, said, “Now you’re on your oath, you
know.
label: neutral

text:
And never believe me on mine, if Pip shan’t make a gentleman on
you!”
label: anger

text: Chapter XLI.
label: neutral

text:
In vain should I attempt to describe the astonishment and disquiet of
Herbert, when he and I and Provis sat down before the fire, and I
recounted the whole of the secret.
label: fear

text:
Enough, that I saw my own feelings
reflected in Herbert’s face, and not least among them, my repugnance
towards the man who had done so much for me.
label: disgust

text:
What would alone have set a division between that man and us, if there
had been no other dividing circumstance, was his triumph in my story.
label: neutral

text:
Saving his troublesome sense of having been “low” on one occasion since
his return,—on which point he began to hold forth to Herbert, the
moment my revelation was finished,—he had no perception of the
possibility of my finding any fault with my good fortune.
label: anger

text:
His boast
that he had made me a gentleman, and that he had come to see me support
the character on his ample resources, was made for me quite as much as
for himself.
label: neutral

text:
And that it was a highly agreeable boast to both of us,
and that we must both be very proud of it, was a conclusion quite
established in his own mind.
label: joy

text:
“Though, look’ee here, Pip’s comrade,” he said to Herbert, after having
discoursed for some time, “I know very well that once since I come
back—for half a minute—I’ve been low.
label: neutral

text:
I said to Pip, I knowed as I had
been low.
label: sadness

text: But don’t you fret yourself on that score.
label: fear

text:
I ain’t made Pip a
gentleman, and Pip ain’t a-going to make you a gentleman, not fur me
not to know what’s due to ye both.
label: neutral

text:
Dear boy, and Pip’s comrade, you two
may count upon me always having a genteel muzzle on.
label: neutral

text:
Muzzled I have
been since that half a minute when I was betrayed into lowness, muzzled
I am at the present time, muzzled I ever will be.”
label: neutral

text:
Herbert said, “Certainly,” but looked as if there were no specific
consolation in this, and remained perplexed and dismayed.
label: surprise

text:
We were
anxious for the time when he would go to his lodging and leave us
together, but he was evidently jealous of leaving us together, and sat
late.
label: fear

text:
It was midnight before I took him round to Essex Street, and saw
him safely in at his own dark door.
label: fear

text:
When it closed upon him, I
experienced the first moment of relief I had known since the night of
his arrival.
label: fear

text:
Never quite free from an uneasy remembrance of the man on the stairs, I
had always looked about me in taking my guest out after dark, and in
bringing him back; and I looked about me now.
label: fear

text:
Difficult as it is in a
large city to avoid the suspicion of being watched, when the mind is
conscious of danger in that regard, I could not persuade myself that
any of the people within sight cared about my movements.
label: fear

text:
The few who
were passing passed on their several ways, and the street was empty
when I turned back into the Temple.
label: disgust

text:
Nobody had come out at the gate
with us, nobody went in at the gate with me.
label: fear

text:
As I crossed by the
fountain, I saw his lighted back windows looking bright and quiet, and,
when I stood for a few moments in the doorway of the building where I
lived, before going up the stairs, Garden Court was as still and
lifeless as the staircase was when I ascended it.
label: fear

text:
Herbert received me with open arms, and I had never felt before so
blessedly what it is to have a friend.
label: joy

text:
When he had spoken some sound
words of sympathy and encouragement, we sat down to consider the
question, What was to be done?
label: neutral

text:
The chair that Provis had occupied still remaining where it had
stood,—for he had a barrack way with him of hanging about one spot, in
one unsettled manner, and going through one round of observances with
his pipe and his negro-head and his jackknife and his pack of cards,
and what not, as if it were all put down for him on a slate,—I say his
chair remaining where it had stood, Herbert unconsciously took it, but
next moment started out of it, pushed it away, and took another.
label: neutral

text:
He had
no occasion to say after that that he had conceived an aversion for my
patron, neither had I occasion to confess my own.
label: disgust

text:
We interchanged that
confidence without shaping a syllable.
label: neutral

text:
“What,” said I to Herbert, when he was safe in another chair,—“what is
to be done?”
label: surprise

text:
“My poor dear Handel,” he replied, holding his head, “I am too stunned
to think.”
label: surprise

text: “So was I, Herbert, when the blow first fell.
label: fear

text:
Still, something must be
done.
label: neutral

text:
He is intent upon various new expenses,—horses, and carriages,
and lavish appearances of all kinds.
label: neutral

text: He must be stopped somehow.”
label: anger

text: “You mean that you can’t accept—”
label: anger

text: “How can I?” I interposed, as Herbert paused.
label: fear

text: “Think of him!
label: anger

text:
Look at
him!”
label: anger

text: An involuntary shudder passed over both of us.
label: fear

text:
“Yet I am afraid the dreadful truth is, Herbert, that he is attached to
me, strongly attached to me.
label: fear

text: Was there ever such a fate!”
label: surprise

text: “My poor dear Handel,” Herbert repeated.
label: sadness

text:
“Then,” said I, “after all, stopping short here, never taking another
penny from him, think what I owe him already!
label: anger

text:
Then again: I am heavily
in debt,—very heavily for me, who have now no expectations,—and I have
been bred to no calling, and I am fit for nothing.”
label: sadness

text: “Well, well, well!” Herbert remonstrated.
label: disgust

text: “Don’t say fit for nothing.”
label: anger

text: “What am I fit for?
label: neutral

text:
I know only one thing that I am fit for, and that
is, to go for a soldier.
label: neutral

text:
And I might have gone, my dear Herbert, but
for the prospect of taking counsel with your friendship and affection.”
label: fear

text:
Of course I broke down there: and of course Herbert, beyond seizing a
warm grip of my hand, pretended not to know it.
label: anger

text: “Anyhow, my dear Handel,” said he presently, “soldiering won’t do.
label: neutral

text:
If
you were to renounce this patronage and these favours, I suppose you
would do so with some faint hope of one day repaying what you have
already had.
label: fear

text: Not very strong, that hope, if you went soldiering!
label: neutral

text: Besides, it’s absurd.
label: disgust

text:
You would be infinitely better in Clarriker’s
house, small as it is.
label: neutral

text:
I am working up towards a partnership, you
know.”
label: neutral

text: Poor fellow!
label: sadness

text: He little suspected with whose money.
label: disgust

text: “But there is another question,” said Herbert.
label: neutral

text:
“This is an ignorant,
determined man, who has long had one fixed idea.
label: disgust

text:
More than that, he
seems to me (I may misjudge him) to be a man of a desperate and fierce
character.”
label: fear

text: “I know he is,” I returned.
label: neutral

text:
“Let me tell you what evidence I have seen
of it.” And I told him what I had not mentioned in my narrative, of
that encounter with the other convict.
label: neutral

text: “See, then,” said Herbert; “think of this!
label: anger

text:
He comes here at the peril
of his life, for the realisation of his fixed idea.
label: fear

text:
In the moment of
realisation, after all his toil and waiting, you cut the ground from
under his feet, destroy his idea, and make his gains worthless to him.
label: anger

text: Do you see nothing that he might do, under the disappointment?”
label: disgust

text:
“I have seen it, Herbert, and dreamed of it, ever since the fatal night
of his arrival.
label: fear

text:
Nothing has been in my thoughts so distinctly as his
putting himself in the way of being taken.”
label: fear

text:
“Then you may rely upon it,” said Herbert, “that there would be great
danger of his doing it.
label: neutral

text:
That is his power over you as long as he
remains in England, and that would be his reckless course if you
forsook him.”
label: anger

text:
I was so struck by the horror of this idea, which had weighed upon me
from the first, and the working out of which would make me regard
myself, in some sort, as his murderer, that I could not rest in my
chair, but began pacing to and fro.
label: fear

text:
I said to Herbert, meanwhile, that
even if Provis were recognised and taken, in spite of himself, I should
be wretched as the cause, however innocently.
label: sadness

text:
Yes; even though I was so
wretched in having him at large and near me, and even though I would
far rather have worked at the forge all the days of my life than I
would ever have come to this!
label: fear

text: But there was no staving off the question, What was to be done?
label: neutral

text:
“The first and the main thing to be done,” said Herbert, “is to get him
out of England.
label: neutral

text:
You will have to go with him, and then he may be
induced to go.”
label: neutral

text: “But get him where I will, could I prevent his coming back?”
label: fear

text:
“My good Handel, is it not obvious that with Newgate in the next
street, there must be far greater hazard in your breaking your mind to
him and making him reckless, here, than elsewhere?
label: neutral

text:
If a pretext to get
him away could be made out of that other convict, or out of anything
else in his life, now.”
label: anger

text:
“There, again!” said I, stopping before Herbert, with my open hands
held out, as if they contained the desperation of the case.
label: fear

text:
“I know
nothing of his life.
label: disgust

text:
It has almost made me mad to sit here of a night
and see him before me, so bound up with my fortunes and misfortunes,
and yet so unknown to me, except as the miserable wretch who terrified
me two days in my childhood!”
label: fear

text:
Herbert got up, and linked his arm in mine, and we slowly walked to and
fro together, studying the carpet.
label: disgust

text:
“Handel,” said Herbert, stopping, “you feel convinced that you can take
no further benefits from him; do you?”
label: joy

text: “Fully.
label: fear

text: Surely you would, too, if you were in my place?”
label: neutral

text: “And you feel convinced that you must break with him?”
label: joy

text: “Herbert, can you ask me?”
label: neutral

text:
“And you have, and are bound to have, that tenderness for the life he
has risked on your account, that you must save him, if possible, from
throwing it away.
label: neutral

text:
Then you must get him out of England before you stir
a finger to extricate yourself.
label: anger

text:
That done, extricate yourself, in
Heaven’s name, and we’ll see it out together, dear old boy.”
label: disgust

text:
It was a comfort to shake hands upon it, and walk up and down again,
with only that done.
label: fear

text:
“Now, Herbert,” said I, “with reference to gaining some knowledge of
his history.
label: neutral

text: There is but one way that I know of.
label: neutral

text:
I must ask him point
blank.”
label: neutral

text: “Yes.
label: neutral

text:
Ask him,” said Herbert, “when we sit at breakfast in the
morning.” For he had said, on taking leave of Herbert, that he would
come to breakfast with us.
label: neutral

text: With this project formed, we went to bed.
label: neutral

text:
I had the wildest dreams
concerning him, and woke unrefreshed; I woke, too, to recover the fear
which I had lost in the night, of his being found out as a returned
transport.
label: fear

text: Waking, I never lost that fear.
label: fear

text:
He came round at the appointed time, took out his jackknife, and sat
down to his meal.
label: neutral

text:
He was full of plans “for his gentleman’s coming out
strong, and like a gentleman,” and urged me to begin speedily upon the
pocket-book which he had left in my possession.
label: neutral

text:
He considered the
chambers and his own lodging as temporary residences, and advised me to
look out at once for a “fashionable crib” near Hyde Park, in which he
could have “a shake-down.” When he had made an end of his breakfast,
and was wiping his knife on his leg, I said to him, without a word of
preface,—
label: fear

text:
“After you were gone last night, I told my friend of the struggle that
the soldiers found you engaged in on the marshes, when we came up.
label: fear

text:
You
remember?”
label: surprise

text: “Remember!” said he.
label: neutral

text: “I think so!”
label: joy

text: “We want to know something about that man—and about you.
label: neutral

text:
It is strange
to know no more about either, and particularly you, than I was able to
tell last night.
label: surprise

text:
Is not this as good a time as another for our knowing
more?”
label: neutral

text: “Well!” he said, after consideration.
label: anger

text:
“You’re on your oath, you know,
Pip’s comrade?”
label: neutral

text: “Assuredly,” replied Herbert.
label: neutral

text: “As to anything I say, you know,” he insisted.
label: neutral

text:
“The oath applies to
all.”
label: neutral

text: “I understand it to do so.”
label: neutral

text: “And look’ee here!
label: anger

text:
Wotever I done is worked out and paid for,” he
insisted again.
label: neutral

text: “So be it.”
label: neutral

text:
He took out his black pipe and was going to fill it with negro-head,
when, looking at the tangle of tobacco in his hand, he seemed to think
it might perplex the thread of his narrative.
label: neutral

text:
He put it back again,
stuck his pipe in a button-hole of his coat, spread a hand on each
knee, and after turning an angry eye on the fire for a few silent
moments, looked round at us and said what follows.
label: anger

text: Chapter XLII.
label: neutral

text: “Dear boy and Pip’s comrade.
label: sadness

text:
I am not a-going fur to tell you my life
like a song, or a story-book.
label: neutral

text:
But to give it you short and handy, I’ll
put it at once into a mouthful of English.
label: neutral

text:
In jail and out of jail, in
jail and out of jail, in jail and out of jail.
label: sadness

text: There, you’ve got it.
label: neutral

text:
That’s _my_ life pretty much, down to such times as I got shipped off,
arter Pip stood my friend.
label: neutral

text: “I’ve been done everything to, pretty well—except hanged.
label: neutral

text:
I’ve been
locked up as much as a silver tea-kittle.
label: neutral

text:
I’ve been carted here and
carted there, and put out of this town, and put out of that town, and
stuck in the stocks, and whipped and worried and drove.
label: anger

text:
I’ve no more
notion where I was born than you have—if so much.
label: surprise

text:
I first become aware
of myself down in Essex, a thieving turnips for my living.
label: disgust

text:
Summun had
run away from me—a man—a tinker—and he’d took the fire with him, and
left me wery cold.
label: fear

text: “I know’d my name to be Magwitch, chrisen’d Abel.
label: neutral

text: How did I know it?
label: surprise

text:
Much as I know’d the birds’ names in the hedges to be chaffinch,
sparrer, thrush.
label: neutral

text:
I might have thought it was all lies together, only as
the birds’ names come out true, I supposed mine did.
label: neutral

text:
“So fur as I could find, there warn’t a soul that see young Abel
Magwitch, with us little on him as in him, but wot caught fright at
him, and either drove him off, or took him up.
label: fear

text:
I was took up, took up,
took up, to that extent that I reg’larly grow’d up took up.
label: neutral

text:
“This is the way it was, that when I was a ragged little creetur as
much to be pitied as ever I see (not that I looked in the glass, for
there warn’t many insides of furnished houses known to me), I got the
name of being hardened.
label: neutral

text:
‘This is a terrible hardened one,’ they says to
prison wisitors, picking out me.
label: disgust

text:
‘May be said to live in jails, this
boy.’ Then they looked at me, and I looked at them, and they measured
my head, some on ’em,—they had better a measured my stomach,—and others
on ’em giv me tracts what I couldn’t read, and made me speeches what I
couldn’t understand.
label: disgust

text: They always went on agen me about the Devil.
label: disgust

text:
But
what the Devil was I to do?
label: sadness

text:
I must put something into my stomach,
mustn’t I?—Howsomever, I’m a getting low, and I know what’s due.
label: neutral

text:
Dear
boy and Pip’s comrade, don’t you be afeerd of me being low.
label: neutral

text:
“Tramping, begging, thieving, working sometimes when I could,—though
that warn’t as often as you may think, till you put the question
whether you would ha’ been over-ready to give me work yourselves,—a bit
of a poacher, a bit of a labourer, a bit of a wagoner, a bit of a
haymaker, a bit of a hawker, a bit of most things that don’t pay and
lead to trouble, I got to be a man.
label: fear

text:
A deserting soldier in a
Traveller’s Rest, what lay hid up to the chin under a lot of taturs,
learnt me to read; and a travelling Giant what signed his name at a
penny a time learnt me to write.
label: neutral

text:
I warn’t locked up as often now as
formerly, but I wore out my good share of key-metal still.
label: sadness

text:
“At Epsom races, a matter of over twenty years ago, I got acquainted
wi’ a man whose skull I’d crack wi’ this poker, like the claw of a
lobster, if I’d got it on this hob.
label: neutral

text:
His right name was Compeyson; and
that’s the man, dear boy, what you see me a pounding in the ditch,
according to what you truly told your comrade arter I was gone last
night.
label: neutral

text:
“He set up fur a gentleman, this Compeyson, and he’d been to a public
boarding-school and had learning.
label: neutral

text:
He was a smooth one to talk, and was
a dab at the ways of gentlefolks.
label: neutral

text: He was good-looking too.
label: joy

text:
It was the
night afore the great race, when I found him on the heath, in a booth
that I know’d on.
label: surprise

text:
Him and some more was a sitting among the tables when
I went in, and the landlord (which had a knowledge of me, and was a
sporting one) called him out, and said, ‘I think this is a man that
might suit you,’—meaning I was.
label: surprise

text: “Compeyson, he looks at me very noticing, and I look at him.
label: neutral

text:
He has a
watch and a chain and a ring and a breast-pin and a handsome suit of
clothes.
label: neutral

text: “‘To judge from appearances, you’re out of luck,’ says Compeyson to me.
label: neutral

text:
“‘Yes, master, and I’ve never been in it much.’ (I had come out of
Kingston Jail last on a vagrancy committal.
label: neutral

text:
Not but what it might have
been for something else; but it warn’t.)
label: neutral

text: “‘Luck changes,’ says Compeyson; ‘perhaps yours is going to change.’
label: neutral

text: “I says, ‘I hope it may be so.
label: neutral

text: There’s room.’
label: neutral

text: “‘What can you do?’ says Compeyson.
label: fear

text: “‘Eat and drink,’ I says; ‘if you’ll find the materials.’
label: neutral

text:
“Compeyson laughed, looked at me again very noticing, giv me five
shillings, and appointed me for next night.
label: joy

text: Same place.
label: neutral

text:
“I went to Compeyson next night, same place, and Compeyson took me on
to be his man and pardner.
label: neutral

text:
And what was Compeyson’s business in which
we was to go pardners?
label: neutral

text:
Compeyson’s business was the swindling,
handwriting forging, stolen bank-note passing, and such-like.
label: neutral

text:
All sorts
of traps as Compeyson could set with his head, and keep his own legs
out of and get the profits from and let another man in for, was
Compeyson’s business.
label: neutral

text:
He’d no more heart than a iron file, he was as
cold as death, and he had the head of the Devil afore mentioned.
label: disgust

text:
“There was another in with Compeyson, as was called Arthur,—not as
being so chrisen’d, but as a surname.
label: neutral

text:
He was in a Decline, and was a
shadow to look at.
label: disgust

text:
Him and Compeyson had been in a bad thing with a
rich lady some years afore, and they’d made a pot of money by it; but
Compeyson betted and gamed, and he’d have run through the king’s taxes.
label: neutral

text:
So, Arthur was a dying, and a dying poor and with the horrors on him,
and Compeyson’s wife (which Compeyson kicked mostly) was a having pity
on him when she could, and Compeyson was a having pity on nothing and
nobody.
label: disgust

text:
“I might a took warning by Arthur, but I didn’t; and I won’t pretend I
was partick’ler—for where ’ud be the good on it, dear boy and comrade?
label: neutral

text: So I begun wi’ Compeyson, and a poor tool I was in his hands.
label: sadness

text:
Arthur
lived at the top of Compeyson’s house (over nigh Brentford it was), and
Compeyson kept a careful account agen him for board and lodging, in
case he should ever get better to work it out.
label: neutral

text:
But Arthur soon settled
the account.
label: neutral

text:
The second or third time as ever I see him, he come a
tearing down into Compeyson’s parlour late at night, in only a flannel
gown, with his hair all in a sweat, and he says to Compeyson’s wife,
‘Sally, she really is upstairs alonger me, now, and I can’t get rid of
her.
label: neutral

text:
She’s all in white,’ he says, ‘wi’ white flowers in her hair, and
she’s awful mad, and she’s got a shroud hanging over her arm, and she
says she’ll put it on me at five in the morning.’
label: disgust

text:
“Says Compeyson: ‘Why, you fool, don’t you know she’s got a living
body?
label: anger

text:
And how should she be up there, without coming through the door,
or in at the window, and up the stairs?’
label: fear

text:
“‘I don’t know how she’s there,’ says Arthur, shivering dreadful with
the horrors, ‘but she’s standing in the corner at the foot of the bed,
awful mad.
label: fear

text:
And over where her heart’s broke—_you_ broke it!—there’s
drops of blood.’
label: sadness

text: “Compeyson spoke hardy, but he was always a coward.
label: disgust

text:
‘Go up alonger this
drivelling sick man,’ he says to his wife, ‘and Magwitch, lend her a
hand, will you?’ But he never come nigh himself.
label: fear

text:
“Compeyson’s wife and me took him up to bed agen, and he raved most
dreadful.
label: neutral

text: ‘Why look at her!’ he cries out.
label: anger

text:
‘She’s a shaking the shroud
at me!
label: fear

text: Don’t you see her?
label: anger

text: Look at her eyes!
label: anger

text:
Ain’t it awful to see her
so mad?’ Next he cries, ‘She’ll put it on me, and then I’m done for!
label: disgust

text:
Take it away from her, take it away!’ And then he catched hold of us,
and kep on a talking to her, and answering of her, till I half believed
I see her myself.
label: anger

text:
“Compeyson’s wife, being used to him, giv him some liquor to get the
horrors off, and by and by he quieted.
label: fear

text: ‘O, she’s gone!
label: surprise

text:
Has her keeper
been for her?’ he says.
label: neutral

text: ‘Yes,’ says Compeyson’s wife.
label: neutral

text:
‘Did you tell him
to lock her and bar her in?’ ‘Yes.’ ‘And to take that ugly thing away
from her?’ ‘Yes, yes, all right.’ ‘You’re a good creetur,’ he says,
‘don’t leave me, whatever you do, and thank you!’
label: anger

text:
“He rested pretty quiet till it might want a few minutes of five, and
then he starts up with a scream, and screams out, ‘Here she is!
label: anger

text:
She’s
got the shroud again.
label: neutral

text: She’s unfolding it.
label: neutral

text:
She’s coming out of the
corner.
label: neutral

text: She’s coming to the bed.
label: neutral

text:
Hold me, both on you—one of each
side—don’t let her touch me with it.
label: fear

text: Hah!
label: joy

text: she missed me that time.
label: sadness

text: Don’t let her throw it over my shoulders.
label: fear

text:
Don’t let her lift me up to
get it round me.
label: anger

text: She’s lifting me up.
label: neutral

text:
Keep me down!’ Then he lifted
himself up hard, and was dead.
label: anger

text: “Compeyson took it easy as a good riddance for both sides.
label: neutral

text:
Him and me
was soon busy, and first he swore me (being ever artful) on my own
book,—this here little black book, dear boy, what I swore your comrade
on.
label: anger

text:
“Not to go into the things that Compeyson planned, and I done—which ’ud

that man got me into such nets as made me his black slave.
label: disgust

text:
I was always
in debt to him, always under his thumb, always a working, always a
getting into danger.
label: fear

text:
He was younger than me, but he’d got craft, and
he’d got learning, and he overmatched me five hundred times told and no
mercy.
label: neutral

text: My Missis as I had the hard time wi’—Stop though!
label: anger

text:
I ain’t
brought _her_ in—”

text:
He looked about him in a confused way, as if he had lost his place in

spread his hands broader on his knees, and lifted them off and put them

text: “There ain’t no need to go into it,” he said, looking round once more.

text:
“The time wi’ Compeyson was a’most as hard a time as ever I had; that

text:
Did I tell you as I was tried, alone, for
misdemeanor, while with Compeyson?”
label: fear

text: I answered, No.
label: neutral

text: “Well!” he said, “I _was_, and got convicted.
label: anger

text:
As to took up on

label: neutral

text:
At last, me and Compeyson was both
committed for felony,—on a charge of putting stolen notes in
circulation,—and there was other charges behind.
label: neutral

text:
Compeyson says to me,
‘Separate defences, no communication,’ and that was all.

text:
And I was so
